title: [$250] Optimize `getOptionData`

labels.name: Reviewing
labels.description: Has a PR in review

labels.name: External
labels.description: Added to denote the issue can be worked on by a contributor

labels.name: Weekly
labels.description: KSv2

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Something is broken. Auto assigns a BugZero manager.

body:
### Background The Expensify app’s left-hand navigation (LHN) sidebar lists reports. Each report needs option metadata for display. This involves filtering participants (e.g., hiding the current user, handling visibility rules) and tracking report attributes for React re-renders. The `getOptionData` function prepares this data and is called frequently. `OptionRowLHNData` wraps it in `useMemo` to avoid unnecessary recalculations, but the current setup still causes performance bottlenecks. ### Problem When user is in Most Recent mode, and the sidebar renders options for a large amount of reports, it calls `getParticipantsAccountIDsForDisplay` multiple times with different parameters and tracks unnecessary dependencies in React’s useMemo hook, which causes redundant computation of participant filtering logic and unnecessary re-renders when irrelevant report attributes change, which prevents the sidebar from rendering efficiently. ### Solution Reduce `getParticipantsAccountIDsForDisplay` function calls by extracting part of the logic responsible for filtering the results for different use cases into separate function so it’s not needed to call the original function multiple times. Additionally, remove `reportAttributes` from the `useMemo` dependency array. `getOptionData` only uses three properties from it: `reportName`, `brickRoadStatus` and `reportErrors`. The first two are already included in the array, and we should explicitly check whether the `reportErrors` object has changed to avoid unnecessary calls. On iOS, when creating a new chat with ~2k reports and ~28k personal details, `getOptionData` time went from **~900ms** to **~150ms.**

  • Upwork Job ID: 1966548664039373006

3. Go to Report page
4. Hover over the avatars at the header

The cursor should be of type `pointer`, as the avatar can be clicked on
## Actual Result:
The cursor is of text type, which leads to poor UX

Unknown
